definition: To examine something in detail in order to understand it better or draw conclusions.
examples: We will analyse the survey results in class.
Scientists analysed the rock samples.

extra.memory_tip: Analyse = break it into parts and look closely.

definition: Worried or fearful that something bad might happen.
examples: She felt apprehensive before the exam.
He was apprehensive about the storm.

definition: To happen at the same time; to match exactly in position or idea.
examples: The festival dates coincide with our trip.
Her view coincides with mine.

extra.memory_tip: Coincide = two things ‘co’ inside the same time.

definition: To create or write (music, poetry, text); to form or make up; to calm oneself.
examples: She composed a song for the play.
Water is composed of hydrogen and oxygen.

extra.memory_tip: Compose = put parts together with purpose.

definition: A thin, flat, round object; in computing, a device or medium for storing data.
examples: The moon looked like a bright disk.
Save your work to the disk.

extra.memory_tip: Disk = think ‘disc’—a flat round shape or storage.

examples: Fog enveloped the harbour.
Warm blankets enveloped the baby.

extra.memory_tip: Envelop = act like an ‘envelope’ around something.

definition: To be real or present; to live.
examples: Do black swans exist in this region?
Some species exist only on remote islands.

definition: Very unusual or remarkable; beyond the ordinary.
examples: The rescue was an extraordinary effort.
She has an extraordinary memory.

definition: A safety device that breaks an electrical circuit when it’s overloaded; to join or blend into one.
examples: The lights went out because a fuse blew. (noun)
Heat fused the pieces of glass together. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Fuse = either a safety ‘stop’ or a way to ‘join’.

definition: Used to emphasise how small or unimportant something is; nothing more than.
examples: It was a mere scratch.
A mere five minutes remained.

definition: To move in a circle around a central point; to turn or rotate.
examples: Planets revolve around the sun.
The story revolves around friendship.

definition: A series of marks used for measuring size or level; the size ratio on a map or model; to climb; to remove scales from fish.
examples: Use the scale on the map to find distance. (noun)
They scaled the cliff before noon. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Scale = measure or ‘scale’ up a wall.

examples: Solar panels turn sunlight into electricity.
A solar eclipse happens when the moon blocks the sun.

extra.memory_tip: Solar = think ‘sol’, the Latin word for sun.

definition: To find or follow the course of something; to draw a copy by following lines; a very small amount.
examples: Detectives traced the call to a café. (verb)
There was only a trace of salt left. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Trace = track the trail or outline it.

definition: Speed in a given direction; the rate of motion.
examples: The ball’s velocity increased down the slope.
In physics, velocity includes both speed and direction.

extra.memory_tip: Velocity = ‘velocity of a vehicle’—how fast and where.
